Comment:
Hi Everyone!

I hope you all enjoyed that Part 1 Cameo, now it is time for Part 2.  This time my opponent is currently a Class C player who also had the misfortune to get on the wrong side of Glenda.  How did this happen?  Here is the gameknot analysis version of this game: http://gameknot.com/analyze-board.pl?bd=18378837&fb=1&rnd=0.9658788367717621

2. d4 - this is the Centre Game.  White makes an immediate d4 thrust following e4.  Both bishop's diagonals are now clear.  I decided to capture and the Wicked Witch of the West recaptures.  This centralisation of the enemy queen is a double edged sword.  Can I give her the runaround?  We shall see.

14. Qxb3 - white's lsb is traded off for my knight and I notice there is an undefended pawn on e4.  I ascertain that it is suitable equine fare and my ravenous kingside steed gobbles it up next turn.

23. c3 - prevents the mate but I scent blood.

23. ..... Be6 - Fou Leblanc joins in the fun.  He is heading for b3 where he will put a nasty cramp on the WK and the other white pieces.

24. ..... Bb3 - here white waves the white flag.  Before he did this he told me he was thinking of resignation.  I then told him it was up to him but he would have to give up his queen for my knight to prevent immediate checkmate.  He resigned on the grounds of Ruinous Loss of Material but Gameknot Analysis told me that I did in fact, have a forced mate in 9.  But again, do you think it is wise to underestimate Glenda?  Well, you may have another think coming because her next victim is currently a Class C player and formerly a Class B player with an optimum rating of 1730.  That is up next folks .......
